titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Lacy Family Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 22:01

did.unittitle: Lacy Family Papers
did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, and collected material document the life and work of three generations of the Lacy family. William H. Lacy directed the Foochow Mission Press and, after 1903, the Methodist Publishing House in Shanghai, while his wife Emma Nind Lacy taught at the Anglo-Chinese School in Foochow and elsewhere. Their four sons and one daughter all served as Methodist missionaries in China. Son George Carleton Lacy spent twenty years as general secretary of the American Bible Society in China and became Bishop of the Methodist China Central Conference in 1941. His son, Creighton Lacy, was a missionary to China from 1946 to 1951 and later taught at Duke University Divinity School.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Lacy Family Papers (RG 223), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

chronitem.event: George Carleton Lacy was born in Foochow [Fuzhou], China, son of William Henry and Emma Nind Lacy, Methodist missionaries in China. William H. Lacy directed the Foochow Mission Press and, after 1903, the Methodist Publishing House in Shanghai, while his wife Emma Nind Lacy taught at the Anglo-Chinese School in Foochow and elsewhere. Their four sons and one daughter all of whom served as Methodist missionaries in China. Emma Nind Lacy's mother, Mary Clarke Nind, helped to organize the Woman's Foreign Missionary Society in the North Central states in the U.S. and in the 1890s took a world tour of Methodist mission stations. GCL was educated at mission schools in Foochow and Shanghai
B.A. Ohio Wesleyan University
B.D. Garrett Biblical Institute
M.A. from Northwestern University
Appointed as Methodist missionary to China, arriving in Shanghai in September
After attending the Nanking Language School, GCL was an itinerant missionary in Kiangsi Province, President of William Nast College, and District Superintendent.
Married Harriet Lang Boutelle, who had gone to Canton, China as a YWCA secretary.

Loaned by Methodist Board of Missions to the American Bible Society; served as Secretary of its China Agency and then of the China Bible House formed with the British and Foreign Bible Society. Also served as China correspondent for Zion's Herald and The Christian Century

Studied at Union Theological Seminary and Columbia University in New York while on furlough. Received a second M.A. in 1938. Awarded honorary Doctor of Divinity degrees from Ohio Wesleyan University and Garrett Biblical Institute
Appointed member of the Joint Commission on Unity of the Methodist Episcopal Church and Methodist Episcopal Church, South in China
Elected Bishop of the China Central Conference and assigned to the Foochow area. Traveled extensively in China when his episcopal area was occupied by Japanese troops.

GCL's tenure as Bishop was set to end but the advent of the Communist government made it impossible to hold General Conference or elections. GCL officially resigned and turned his authority over to Bishop W. Y. Chen but he was not granted an exit permit when other missionaries left and was under house arrest.
Died of heart attack while being held at Union Hospital, Foochow.
Creighton Boutelle Lacy born in Kuling, China, son of George Carleton and Harriet Boutelle Lacy. He attended Shanghai American School.
A. B. (summa cum laude) Swarthmore College
B.D. (magna cum laude) Yale Divinity School
Married Frances M. Thompson
Pastor of Grace Methodist Church, New Haven, CT
Methodist missionary to China: taught philosophy at University of Nanking, Bible at the Anglo-Chinese College in Foochow [Fuzhow], theology at Union Theological School in Foochow.
Ph.D. Yale University; thesis: "Protestant Missions in Communist China"

Taught missions and social ethics at Duke University Divinity School, served as Associate Dean and editor of the Duke Divinity School Review. His major publications include Conscience of India; Moral Traditions in the Modern World (1965), Frank Mason North: His Social and Ecumenical Mission (1967), The Word-carrying Giant : the Growth of the American Bible Society 1816-1966 (1977), Coming Home--to China (1978)
Professor Emeritus of Parish Ministry at Duke University Divinity School
Died.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence, writings, and collected material document the life and work of three generations of the Lacy family. Of particular interest are the missionary circular letters and other documents gathered by Creighton Lacy when preparing his dissertation about Protestant missions and the Chinese church at the time of the Communist takeover. Creighton Lacy also gathered biographical information about the Lacy family and transcribed diaries written by his father, Carleton. Papers related to Creighton Lacy's teaching career at Duke University Divinity School are contained in the Creighton Lacy Papers held there.

did.unittitle: Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The letters in Box 1 Folders 5-9 have been digitized and are available under the Lacy Family Papers in the Divinity Library AdHoc Digital Image and Text Database.

did.unittitle: Carleton Lacy

GCL to family from Shanghai
GCL to family, primarily from Foochow, including regarding arrival of Communist army, and regarding activities of Creighton (Corky) who was also in Foochow.
GCL to family from Foochow - regular detailed letters regarding his activities following the Communist takeover and regarding activities of Creighton (Corky) who was also in Foochow.
GCL to family from Foochow, including regarding operations of Methodist Church in China
GCL to family from Foochow, including from Union Hospital, including regarding questioning by police

By Carleton Lacy
"Lacy-Logues" - 2 printed booklets describing the Lacy family travels in 1932 and 1937; typescript document intended as 1944 sequel to Lacy-Logues, found and edited by CBL in 1995
Newspaper article "Aeroplane to Szechuen" from North China Daily News

Articles: "Creative Imagination", "High Spots in the Central Conference" in The China Christian Advocate ; "China, Peace and Propaganda" in The Christian Century ; "The Missionary in the Post-war China" (typescript)
Transcripts of diaries of GCL, including regarding his calling as a missionary, his trip to China, his work in Nanchang, Shanghai, and Kuantseh, Fukien

Booklet: "Jesus for Chinese Youth" - based on M.A. thesis Union Theological Seminary, Columbia University

"Democracy in China" - Honors thesis at Swarthmore College
Student papers and published articles, including ""The Democracy of China" in Asia and the Americas , "Missions are Missing" in Intercollegian , "Frontiers of Faith" in World Outlook

Papers and published articles, including "Christian Missions Confront Communism, 1921-1948", "Five Months to Freedom or Lessons in Liberation", "When Christians Support Marx" in The Christian Century , "The Missionary Exodus from China" in Pacific Affairs
Papers and published articles, including "God's Love... Our Mission" in The Reveille , "Christianity and Communism" in Adult Student
Published articles: "The Banyan Falls" in The American Review , "Motivation for Missions" in The Outlook
Published article: "Confucian-ism in Mao's China" in International Christian University publication
Papers and published articles, including in Duke Divinity School publications
Papers and published articles, including "A History of Christianity in China" in The China Connection , "My Pilgrimage in Mission" in International Bulletin of Missionary Research

Papers and articles, including "China is Young Again: A Student Looks to the Country of his Birth", "The Diaspora from China", response to question "What steps or stages did the Communist regime go through in its treatment of foreign missionaries or missionary institutions?", "A Personal View: The Impact of China on the American Missionary Family"
Chapters: ""Toward a Theology of Public Responsibility" in America and the Future of Theology ; "With Minstrel Heart" in The Hymns of Frank Mason North

Study Guides: "Christian Responsibility for the United States and the New Nations", "Adult Guide on Understanding China", "'Adam, Where Art Thou' - Interpretive report of the Interfield Consultation , St. Simons Island, GA

Including "Methodist Missionary Contributions to Intercultural Understanding and Diplomacy: The Caldwell Family in Fuzhou and Central Fujian, 1912-1949" by Joseph K.S. Yick
